In December 2019, a new coronavirus (SARS-CoV-2) emerged, leading to a pandemic of an 78 acute respiratory syndrome in humans (1). The impact of the pandemic on European 79 countries has been highly variable, and the United Kingdom (UK) has one of the highest case and 80 death rates from COVID-19 in Europe (2).

As in previous outbreaks of infectious disease (e.g. SARS, H1N1 influenza) (3-5), stringent 82 public health measures were implemented to curtail the spread of SARS-CoV-2 (6). However, in the 83 current pandemic, social isolation measures were applied to whole populations rather than limited to 84 those who are known to have been in contact with the virus. This is an unprecedented response by 85 individual governments and the international community.

Until a vaccine against coronavirus or an effective treatment for COVID-19 becomes 87 available, adherence to transmission-reducing behaviours (TRBs) is crucial to protect lives and halt, 88 or at least slow, transmission. Therefore, understanding the factors that determine adherence to 89 TRBs is essential. While TRBs lessen both personal risk of acquiring COVID-19 and population level 90 rates of COVID-19, they may have detrimental impacts on people's health, especially their mental 91 health (7-9). As COVID-19 is thought to spread via contact between individuals through respiratory 108 droplets (14), TRBs, such as physical distancing should be effective to reduce transmission. Indeed, 109 an early modelling study found that physical distancing measures can be effective in reducing the 110 progression of the coronavirus that causes COVID-19, delaying the epidemic peak, and delaying a 111 potential secondary peak (15). In addition to direct social exposure to respiratory droplets, 112 is also thought to spread by contact with infected surfaces and subsequently touching the eyes, nose 113 or mouth (14) . Since face-touching is frequent and habitual (16), prevention of transmission focusses 114 on improving hand hygiene (17). Good hand hygiene means washing your hands frequently, using 115 soap and water, and for at least 20 seconds (18, 19) . Hand washing is advised every time one enters 116 a building, including entering one's home, when you blow your nose, sneeze or cough, and eat or 117 handle food (20). Hand washing has been shown to reduce the incidence of infectious diseases, 118 especially when hand washing is done correctly and at the correct times (21-23).

A study investigating public awareness of hand washing found that higher numbers of Google 120 searches for 'hand washing' were associated with lower spreading speed of COVID-19 in 21 countries 121 including England (24), suggested public interest in and adherence to effective hand washing 122 practices might go hand in hand. In contrast, the evidence for the effectiveness of wearing facemasks 123 or face coverings remains a topic of debate (25, 26) . The WHO reiterated that there is limited 124 evidence that wearing medical masks by the public is an effective preventive measure (27, 28), but 125 have recently changed their advice to recommend non-medical masks of face coverings in settings 126 where physical distancing difficult (29). Wearing of a face covering (including nonmedical face 127 coverings) in places where social distancing is difficult, such as food shops and public transport, has 128 been advised worldwide, including recently at the start of Phase One after the lockdown in Scotland 129 (30).

It is not only necessary for the public to adopt these TRBs, it is also essential that they 131 maintain adherence to TRBs consistently over the long term, certainly until a vaccine or other 132 effective treatments for COVID-19 become available. The CHARIS study will provide insights into TRBs, and how adherence to these TRBs 325 changes over time as the COVID-19 outbreak progresses, and government restrictions are change.

Additionally, this study will identify the beliefs derived from CS-SRM, SCT and PMT, and 327 sociodemographic factors that predict adherence to TRBs. This understanding will support the 328 tailoring and targeting of interventions to improve adherence to TRBs, and support general and 329 mental health. For example, the content of public health messages could be tailored to strengthen 330 beliefs associated with higher levels of adherence, and targeted at communities who are struggling to 331 adhere. Similarly, CHARIS will identify communities with declining mental health enabling support 332 services to be better targeted.

The CHARIS study has several strengths. First, CHARIS is underpinned by evidence-based 336 psychological theories and thus supports a cumulative approach to conceptual development and 337 evidence. CHARIS can draw on a large existing evidence base that informs the measures used, and 338 details how individual constructs are meaningfully related. Use of three universal theories of 339 behaviour avoids the much criticised 'cafeteria' style research that is not conducive to the 340 development of a cumulative approach to evidence building (54, 55). A cumulative approach is vital to 341 support our understanding of the behaviour of populations during a pandemic, which is crucial in 342 circumstances where changing behaviour is the only available route to halting the pandemic. Second, CHARIS will provide fast, real-time, information to support and inform decision 344 making for policy-makers, public health and service commissioners. Third, the weekly data collection, 345 enables fine-grained analyses of people's reactions to government directives and instructions as they 346 are happening. The repeated measurement over 14 waves makes it possible to directly assess the 347 impact of directives and advice from the government for TRBs, in contrast to previous retrospective 348 studies or studies applying hypothetical situations (56). Fourth, our study will start as the Government-349 imposed restrictions went in to Phase One post-lockdown. The restrictions began to be eased, and 350 more people are allowed to go back to their workplaces, and to start to meet with others outside of 351 their own households. The timing of the CHARIS study places it in the unique position to assess 352 (changing) adherence to TRBs, in response to potentially changing beliefs about the behaviours and 353 the illness, as the Scottish government implements new Phases to gradually lift the restrictions.

Moreover, we can assess the effects of prolonged adherence to TRBs, and beliefs about behaviours 355 and illness on mental and general health. Fifth, CHARIS study data is collected via telephone, which 356 requires the survey to be succinct and the questions easily understood. Therefore, the majority of 357 adults will be able to take part in CHARIS, in line with the call that there is a need for more 358 representative research, particularly in vulnerable populations (57, 58). People can be included who 359 do not have online access, who are typically older, who are more deprived, typically those who are 360 also most at risk from COVID-19. Sixth, recruitment will aim for a representative sample, making the 361 findings generalizable to the Scottish population.

Our study also has some limitations. First, the use of a telephone survey necessitates the use 365 of self-report measures only. This is not a limitation in relation to the measurement of beliefs or mental 366 and general perceived health as these are only available for measurement via self-report. However, 367 measuring behaviour by self-report is open to a number of sources of error, including memory errors 368 and social desirability bias. Social desirability to report adherence is likely, however we have mitigated 369 the impact of social desirability where possible by employing the introductory text from the medication 370 adherence reporting scale (45, 46) . To identify who is and is not adhering to the TRBs and who is experiencing mental and 10 general health problems we will perform univariate and multivariate logistic regression analysis, 11 assessing associations between the sociodemographic variables and each of the TRBs and mental 12 and general health outcomes separately. For the weekly report we use a binary outcome of non-13 adherence, defined as people who only sometimes, rarely, or never adhere to the TRBs. For the 14 publications and bimonthly reports we will take the continuous measure into account.

To identify why there is variation in adherence to TRBs and mental and general health we will 16 perform univariate and multivariate logistic regression analysis, assessing associations between the 17 theorised motivational and behavioural factors and each of the TRBs and mental and general health 18 outcomes separately. These analyses will be done on a weekly basis to provide fast, real-time 19 insights.

For the more in-depth bimonthly bulletin analysis we will use cumulative data, in monthly 21 bulletins compounded over 6 weeks, for the publications over the total study period. Multivariate 22 models will be constructed. Multivariate analyses will be performed with logistic regression using the 23 outcome variables, adherence to TRBs and mental and general health as dependent variables. In 24 addition, theories (CS-SMR, SCT, PMT) will be tested using hierarchical multivariate regression 25 analysis.

What might explain (non-)adherence to TRBs and differences in mental and general health 27 among groups of people (e.g. women respond differently from men), will be assessed in a moderation 28 analysis, using the SPSS macro provided by Hayes (60).

To describe the effects of government guidance and media reporting of COVID-19 and 30 examine their influence on people's beliefs and behaviours, we will assess change over time. For continuous effects, each week's data will be included in the model for a time series analysis (linear 32 trend over time). This covariate will be used as a continuous variable with wave 1 = 1, up to wave 33 14 = 14, indicating a change in the odds ratio per week. For effects of a specific event(s), a dummy 34 code for time before and after the event will be included in the regression analysis. Possible 35 interaction terms between the linear trend over time, and other variables will also be assessed.

Analysis will be performed in SPSS (IBM version 25). Statistical significance will be defined as 37 a p-value ≤ 0.05 for all analyses in the weekly reports and p ≤ 0.01 for the bimonthly bulletins, and 38 odds ratios and 95% confidence intervals will be reported were relevant.
